p: Natural polysaccharides can be obtained from different sources like algal origin, e.g., alginate, plant origin, e.g., pectin and gums, microbial origin, e.g., dextran, and animal origin, e.g., chitosan [ 5, 6], and can be considered as an essential functional material that plays important roles in many physiological and biological activities including antioxidant, antitumor, anti-hyperglycemic, and immune regulation activities [ 7, 8]. The use of microbial polysaccharides in the field of biotechnology and biomedical sciences was started many years ago [ 9, 10]. The diversity of sources that could produce polysaccharides made it a substance of choice as starting materials which were modified chemically and used in different medical and non-medical fields [ 11], include food, energy, wood, paper, textiles, fibers, and oil drilling [ 12, 13].
